</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Recent Developments
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On February&nbsp;25, 2016, we entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the agency platform (the "Acquired Businesses") of our
	Manager for $250.0&nbsp;million. The purchase price is to be paid 50% in stock and 50% in cash with the stock component to be paid with 19.23&nbsp;million
	operating partnership units, which was based on a stock price of $6.50 per share. The purchase price is subject to potential adjustment based on changes in the value of the acquired servicing
	portfolio on the closing date. We have the option, at the discretion of the special committee of our Board of Directors, to utilize up to $50.0&nbsp;million of seller financing to satisfy a portion
	of the cash consideration. All of the employees directly related to the Acquired Businesses will become a part of the Company following the consummation of the transaction.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	addition, we obtained a two year option for $25.0&nbsp;million to purchase the existing management contract and fully internalize the management structure. The exercise of this
	option is at the discretion of the special committee of the Board of Directors, which has no obligation to exercise its option.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	transaction will require certain government and GSE approvals as well as a stockholder vote and other third party approvals. The transaction is expected to close during the third
	quarter of 2016; however, there can be no assurances that the transaction will be completed during this period or at all.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Current Market Conditions, Risks and Recent Trends
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our ability to execute our business strategy, particularly the growth of our portfolio of loans and investments, is dependent on many
	factors, including our ability to access capital and financing on favorable terms. The impact of the previous economic downturn had a significant negative impact on both us and our borrowers. If
	similar economic conditions recur in the future, it may limit our options for raising capital and obtaining financing on favorable terms and may also adversely impact the creditworthiness of our
	borrowers which could result in their inability to repay their loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	rely on the capital markets to generate capital for financing the growth of our business. During 2015, we closed two collateralized securitization offerings, whereby we issued
	$486.8&nbsp;million of investment grade notes. We also entered into four new financing facilities for total availability of $278.5&nbsp;million, of which, one facility for $87.0&nbsp;million was
	repaid upon the repayment of a defaulted first mortgage note in the second quarter of 2015. While there can be no assurance that we will continue to have access to the equity and debt markets, we will
	continue to pursue these and other available market opportunities as a means to increase our liquidity and capital base. If we were to experience another prolonged downturn in the stock or credit
	markets, it could cause us to seek alternative sources of potentially less attractive financing, and may require us to adjust our business plan accordingly.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	commercial real estate markets continue to improve, but uncertainty remains as a result of global market instability, the current political climate and other matters and their
	potential impact on the U.S. economy. If real estate values decline again, it may limit our new mortgage loan originations since
	borrowers often use increases in the value of their existing properties to support the purchase or investment in additional properties. Declining real estate values may also significantly increase the
	likelihood that we will incur losses on our loans in the event of default because the value of our collateral may be insufficient to cover our cost on the loan. Any sustained period of increased
	payment delinquencies, foreclosures or losses could adversely affect both our net interest income from loans as well as our ability to originate, sell and securitize loans, which would significantly
	impact our revenues, results of operations, financial condition, business prospects and our ability to make distributions to our stockholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	recent economic environment has resulted in continued improvement in commercial real estate values which has generally increased payoffs and reduced the credit exposure in our loan
	and
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	39
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=42,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=497422,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DM76901A.;11',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;15:13' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM76901_1_40">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	investment
	portfolio. During 2015, we recorded $6.5&nbsp;million of new provisions for loan losses, primarily due to declining collateral values, and $2.0&nbsp;million in net recoveries of
	reserves. During 2014, we recorded $9.0&nbsp;million of new provisions for loan losses, due to declining collateral values, and $9.3&nbsp;million in net recoveries of reserves. In addition, during
	2014, we recorded impairment losses on a real estate owned asset of $0.3&nbsp;million. No such losses were recorded in 2015. We have made, and continue to make modifications and extensions to loans
	when it is economically feasible to do so. In some cases, a modification is a more viable alternative to foreclosure proceedings when a borrower cannot comply with loan terms. In doing so, lower
	borrower interest rates, combined with non-performing loans, would lower our net interest margins when comparing interest income to our costs of financing. However, since 2013, the levels of
	modifications and extensions have declined and repayments of loans increased as borrowers' access to financing improved. If the markets were to deteriorate and another prolonged economic downturn was
	to occur, we believe there could be additional loan modifications and delinquencies which may result in reduced net interest margins and additional losses throughout our sector. Refer to
	Item&nbsp;1A of this report for additional risk factors.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Primary Sources of Operating Revenues
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We derive our operating revenues primarily through interest received from making real estate-related bridge, mezzanine and junior
	participation loans and preferred equity investments. Interest income earned on these loans and investments represented approximately 80%, 76% and 75% of our total revenues in 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property
	operating income is derived from our hotel and multifamily real estate owned assets. Property operating income represented approximately 19%, 23% and 23% of our total revenues
	in 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. The operation of a portfolio of hotel properties that we own is seasonal with the majority of revenues earned in the first two quarters of the calendar year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Changes in Financial Condition
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Assets&#151;Comparison of balances at December&nbsp;31, 2015 to December&nbsp;31,
	2014:
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash and cash equivalents increased $138.3&nbsp;million primarily due to loan payoffs and interest from our investments as well as
	proceeds from the unwinding of several of our CDO/CLO vehicles, net of funding new loan originations and investments and payment of distributions to our stockholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Restricted
	cash decreased $169.8&nbsp;million primarily due to the unwinding of all of our CDO vehicles and one of our CLO vehicles and is net of issuance proceeds available from our
	fourth and fifth CLOs. Restricted cash is kept on deposit with the trustees for our CLOs, and primarily represents proceeds received from loan payoffs and paydowns that have not yet been disbursed to
	bondholders or redeployed into new assets, as well as unfunded loan commitments and interest payments received from loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	loan and investment portfolio balance, including our available-for-sale securities, was $1.56&nbsp;billion and $1.59&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014,
	respectively. The decrease in our portfolio balance was primarily due to loan payoffs and other reductions exceeding loan originations, see below for details.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	portfolio had a weighted average current interest pay rate of 5.63% and 5.44% at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Including certain fees and costs associated with the
	loan and investment portfolio, the weighted average current interest rate was 6.32% and 6.16%, respectively. Advances on our financing facilities totaled $1.18&nbsp;billion and $1.23&nbsp;billion
	at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively, with a weighted average funding cost of 3.70% and 3.65%, respectively, which excludes changes in the market value of certain interest rate swaps and
	financing costs. Including the financing costs, the weighted average funding rate was 4.12% and 4.07%, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	40
</FONT>
</P>

	$8.4&nbsp;million loan with a $2.5&nbsp;million reserve to real estate owned, net.

	paid off in April 2015.

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	allowance for loan losses was $86.8&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, a decrease of $28.7&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2014 primarily due to the write-off of a
	fully reserved junior participation loan for $32.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Since
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, we have originated 11 new loans for a total of $138.6&nbsp;million and received a total of $8.5&nbsp;million for the repayment in full of three loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments
	in equity affiliates increased $26.0&nbsp;million primarily as a result of $19.3&nbsp;million in total investments we made in a residential mortgage banking business and
	$6.6&nbsp;million of income from equity affiliates recognized on these investments during 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Real
	estate owned decreased $24.1&nbsp;million primarily from reclassifying three Hotel Portfolio properties with an aggregate carrying value of $26.2&nbsp;million to held-for-sale
	in connection with the sale of these properties, partially offset by the acquisition of a $5.9&nbsp;million office building by deed in lieu of foreclosure. The $5.7&nbsp;million decrease in real
	estate held-for-sale is primarily the result of the sale of four held-for-sale properties, partially offset by reclassifying the three Hotel Portfolio properties as described above. We sold the
	properties for $41.1&nbsp;million, recognizing a gain of $7.8&nbsp;million and paid off a related mortgage note payable of $9.1&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liabilities&#151;Comparison of balances at December&nbsp;31, 2015 to
	December&nbsp;31, 2014:
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit facilities and repurchase agreements decreased $43.8&nbsp;million primarily due to paying down the facilities with a portion
	of the proceeds from the issuance of CLO IV and CLO V, partially offset by utilizing a portion of three new financing facilities with total capacity of $191.5&nbsp;million, as well as increasing the
	capacity of an existing facility by $15.0&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Collateralized
	loan obligations increased $305.8&nbsp;million primarily due to the completion of our fourth collateralized securitization in the first quarter of 2015 where we issued
	$219.0&nbsp;million of CLO notes, and the completion of our fifth collateralized securitization in the third quarter of 2015 where we issued $267.8&nbsp;million of CLO notes, partially offset by
	the unwind of CLO II totaling $177.0&nbsp;million in the first quarter of 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Collateralized
	debt obligations decreased $331.2&nbsp;million due to the unwind of CDO I and CDO II in the first quarter of 2015 and CDO III in the third quarter of 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">

</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Equity activity in 2015 consisted of the issuance of 402,694 shares of restricted stock to employees of ours and our Manager, including
	our chief executive officer, and 83,430 shares to the independent members of the Board of Directors. We also issued up to 445,765 performance-based restricted
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=44,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1035636,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DM76901A.;11',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;15:13' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM76901_1_42">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	common
	stock units to our chief executive officer that vest at the end of a four-year performance period subject to meeting certain total stockholder return objectives. See
	Note&nbsp;12&#151;"Equity" of this report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
	of February&nbsp;26, 2016, we have $330.4&nbsp;million available under our $500.0&nbsp;million shelf registration statement that was declared effective by the SEC in August
	2013.
</FONT>
</P>

	following table presents dividends declared (on a per share basis) for 2015:

</P>

<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Preferred
	Stock&#151;The dividend declared on February&nbsp;2, 2015 was for the period December&nbsp;1, 2014 through February&nbsp;28, 2015.
	The dividend declared on April&nbsp;29, 2015 was for the period March&nbsp;1, 2015 through May&nbsp;31, 2015. The dividend declared on July&nbsp;29, 2015 was for the period June&nbsp;1, 2015
	through August&nbsp;31, 2015. The dividend declared on November&nbsp;2, 2015 was for the period September&nbsp;1, 2015 through November&nbsp;30, 2015.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Common Stock
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;On February&nbsp;24, 2016, the Board of Directors declared a cash dividend of $0.15 per share of common stock. The dividend is payable
	on March&nbsp;15, 2016 to common stockholders of record as of the close of business on March&nbsp;10, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Preferred Stock
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;On February&nbsp;1, 2016, the Board of Directors declared a cash dividend of $0.515625 per share of 8.25% Series&nbsp;A preferred
	stock; a cash dividend of $0.484375 per share of 7.75% Series&nbsp;B preferred stock; and a cash dividend of $0.53125 per share of 8.50% Series&nbsp;C preferred stock. These amounts reflect
	dividends from December&nbsp;1, 2015 through February&nbsp;29, 2016 and are payable on February&nbsp;29, 2016 to preferred stockholders of record on February&nbsp;15, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>

<FONT SIZE=2>
	42
</FONT>

	&#8203;
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
	&#8203;
<FONT>
</FONT>
</TD>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Based
	on UPB for loans, amortized cost for securities and principal amount for debt.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Weighted
	average yield calculated based on annualized interest income or expense divided by average carrying value.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Interest Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income increased $0.1&nbsp;million in 2015 as compared to 2014. This increase was primarily due to a 3% increase in the
	average yield on core interest-earning assets from 6.47% for 2014 to 6.67% for 2015, due to higher interest rates on our originations as compared to runoff during 2014 and 2015. The increase was
	partially offset by a 3% decrease in our average core interest-earning assets from $1.64&nbsp;billion for 2014 to $1.59&nbsp;billion for 2015, primarily due to loan payoffs exceeding loan
	originations in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	interest income, net was $7.9&nbsp;million for 2015. During the first quarter of 2015, we acquired a $116.0&nbsp;million defaulted first mortgage, at par. In the second quarter
	of 2015, the first mortgage paid off and as a result, we recognized net interest income of $7.9&nbsp;million. There was no such income in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	expense increased $1.8&nbsp;million, or 4%, for 2015 as compared to 2014. The average cost of our interest-bearing liabilities increased 7% from 3.99% for 2014 to 4.25% for
	2015, primarily due to a
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	44
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=47,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=721010,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DO76901A.;6',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:16' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO76901_1_45">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$1.1&nbsp;million
	increase in the acceleration of fees resulting from the unwind of several of our securitization vehicles as compared to 2014, as well as from the issuance of $97.9&nbsp;million
	of senior unsecured notes in 2014, which carry a higher cost of debt. The increase was partially offset by a 2% decrease in the average balance of our interest-bearing liabilities from
	$1.20&nbsp;billion for 2014 to
	$1.17&nbsp;billion for 2015. The decrease in the average balance was primarily due to the corresponding decrease in our average core interest-earning assets, partially offset by the full impact of
	our senior unsecured notes issued in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Other Revenue
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property operating results (income less expenses) are comprised of our Multifamily and Hotel Portfolios as well as an office building.
	Property operating results decreased $0.4&nbsp;million, or 7%, for 2015 as compared to 2014, primarily due to the sales of several properties during 2014 and 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	income, net decreased $1.4&nbsp;million, or 84%, for 2015, as compared to 2014. During 2014, we recognized $0.9&nbsp;million of net interest income and gain on the sale of RMBS
	investments, as well as received $0.6&nbsp;million more in miscellaneous asset management and loan modification fees as compared to 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Other Expenses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee compensation and benefits expense increased $3.5&nbsp;million, or 25%, for 2015 as compared to 2014, primarily due to
	expenses totaling $2.2&nbsp;million related to the $116.0&nbsp;million defaulted first mortgage that was repaid in 2015 and the Lexford distributions received during 2015 as well as a
	$1.0&nbsp;million increase in stock-based compensation due to grants issued in 2014 and 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling
	and administrative expense increased $2.9&nbsp;million, or 30%, for 2015 as compared to 2014. These costs include, but are not limited to, professional and consulting fees,
	marketing costs, insurance expense, travel and placement fees, director's fees, licensing fees and stock-based compensation relating to our directors and certain employees of our Manager. This
	increase was primarily due to professional fees associated with the exploration of a potential transaction with our Manager totaling $3.1&nbsp;million. See "Agreements and Transactions with Related
	Parties" below for further details.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation
	and amortization decreased $1.9&nbsp;million, or 26%, for 2015 as compared to 2014, primarily due to the sale of several properties within our Multifamily and Hotel
	Portfolios during 2014 and 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Provision
	for loan losses (net of recoveries) totaled $4.5&nbsp;million and $(0.3) million for 2015 and 2014, respectively. During 2015, we recognized a $6.5&nbsp;million provision
	for loan losses related to five loans and recorded net recoveries of previously recorded loan losses of $2.0&nbsp;million. During 2014, we recognized a $9.0&nbsp;million provision for loan losses
	related to four loans and recorded net recoveries of previously recorded loan losses of $9.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	fees increased $1.0&nbsp;million, or 10%, for 2015, as compared to 2014. These amounts represent compensation in the form of base management fees, on a cost reimbursement
	basis. The increase in management fees was due to an increase in allocable costs incurred by our Manager in managing our business from 2014 to 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Acceleration of Deferred Income / Loss on Termination of Swaps
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the unwind of CDO I and II in the first quarter of 2015 and CDO III in the third quarter of 2015, we recorded a
	$19.2&nbsp;million gain that was previously deferred due to the reissuance of CDO I, CDO II and CDO III bonds in 2010 as a result of a deferral of the gain from the extinguishment of trust preferred
	debt. See Note&nbsp;7&#151;"Debt Obligations" for more details about this gain. We also terminated the basis and interest rate swaps associated with these CDOs and recognized
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	45
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=48,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=85912,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DO76901A.;6',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:16' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DO76901_1_46">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	a
	loss of $4.6&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;8&#151;"Derivative Financial Instruments" for more details about the swap termination.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Sale of Real Estate
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2015, we sold three properties in our Hotel Portfolio for $28.7&nbsp;million and recognized a gain of $4.8&nbsp;million and
	sold a property in our Multifamily Portfolio for $12.4&nbsp;million recognizing a gain of $3.0&nbsp;million. During 2014, we sold three real estate properties in the Multifamily Portfolio for
	$21.3&nbsp;million and recognized a net gain of $1.6&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Sale of Equity Interest / Incentive Management Fee
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the third quarter of 2014, we recognized a gain of $77.1&nbsp;million as a result of our debt guarantee on the 450 West
	33rd&nbsp;Street property being terminated in connection with a refinancing of the existing debt on this property, net of a $19.0&nbsp;million incentive management fee that was prepaid in relation
	to the transaction. We also recognized a gain on sale of equity interest of $7.9&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2014 due to the sale of an interest in properties held by one of our equity
	affiliates. See Note&nbsp;5&#151;"Investments in Equity Affiliates" for further details. There were no such gains in 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Income from Equity Affiliates
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income from equity affiliates increased $12.1&nbsp;million for 2015 as compared to 2014, primarily due to $6.6&nbsp;million of
	income earned on our investment in a residential mortgage banking business, which we made in the first quarter of 2015, as well as from $5.5&nbsp;million of income from distributions from our
	Lexford investment. See Note&nbsp;5&#151;"Investments in Equity Affiliates" of this report for more details.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	46
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=50,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=99856,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DQ76901A.;8',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:16' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ76901_1_48">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following table presents the average balance of interest-earning assets and related interest-bearing liabilities, associated interest income and expense and the corresponding
	weighted average yields (dollars in thousands):
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_15"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:57%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
</FONT>
</P>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_TABLEWIDTH,"140%" -->

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Based
	on UPB for loans, amortized cost for securities and principal amount for debt.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Weighted
	average yield calculated based on annualized interest income or expense divided by average carrying value.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Net Interest Income
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income increased $7.7&nbsp;million, or 8%, in 2014 as compared to 2013. This increase was primarily due to a 15% increase in
	the average yield on core interest-earning assets from 5.65% for 2013 to 6.47% for 2014, primarily from $4.3&nbsp;million of fee income from accelerated runoff as well as from higher interest rates
	on our portfolio during 2014. The increase was partially offset by a 6% decrease in our average core interest-earning assets from $1.75&nbsp;billion for 2013 to $1.64&nbsp;billion for 2014, due to
	loan payoffs exceeding loan originations by $78.9&nbsp;million and selling our available-for-sale RMBS securities totaling $33.4&nbsp;million during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	expense increased $5.8&nbsp;million, or 14%, for 2014 as compared to 2013. The increase was primarily due to a 24% increase in the average cost of these interest-bearing
	liabilities from 3.22% for 2013 to 3.99% for 2014, primarily due to an overall increase in our CDO debt cost as a result of runoff in these vehicles, the proceeds of which are used to paydown low cost
	debt within these CDO's, $1.0&nbsp;million in accelerated fees related to the redemption of CLO I in December 2014 and the issuance
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	48
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=51,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=694008,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DQ76901A.;8',USER='JTAYLORA',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:16' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DQ76901_1_49">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	of
	$97.9&nbsp;million of 7.375% senior unsecured notes during 2014. The increase was partially offset by an 8% decrease in the average balance of our interest-bearing liabilities from
	$1.30&nbsp;billion for 2013 to $1.20&nbsp;billion for 2014. The decrease in the average balance was primarily due to a decrease in CDO debt due to runoff and decreases in our securities and other
	non-recourse financing, partially offset by the issuance of $281.3&nbsp;million in CLO III notes in April 2014 and the issuance of $97.9&nbsp;million of senior unsecured notes during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Other Revenue
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Property operating results (income less expenses) are comprised of our Multifamily and Hotel Portfolios. Property operating results
	increased $1.4&nbsp;million, or 41%, for 2014 as compared to 2013, primarily due to higher occupancy and increased ancillary income (food and beverage, parking, fees) at our Hotel Portfolio,
	partially offset by increased operating costs at our Hotel Portfolio and the sale of three properties in our Multifamily Portfolio during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	income, net decreased $0.6&nbsp;million, or 28%, for 2014 as compared to 2013, primarily due to a reduction of miscellaneous asset management and other fees.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Other Expenses
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee compensation and benefits expense increased $1.9&nbsp;million, or 16%, for 2014 as compared to 2013. Compensation increased
	$1.5&nbsp;million as a result of our CEO's base salary being directly compensated by us effective January&nbsp;1, 2014, as well as an increase in staffing resulting from higher loan origination
	volume from 2013 to 2014. Additionally, stock-based compensation increased $0.3&nbsp;million related to restricted common stock grants that were awarded to certain employees in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Selling
	and administrative expense decreased $1.0&nbsp;million, or 9%, for 2014 as compared to 2013 primarily due to $1.4&nbsp;million in costs and fees incurred in 2013 in
	connection with the exploration and evaluation of a potential transaction with our Manager. No similar costs were incurred in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Provision
	for loan losses (net of recoveries) totaled $(0.3) million for 2014 and $4.3&nbsp;million for 2013. During 2014, we recognized a $9.0&nbsp;million provision for loan losses
	related to four loans and recorded net recoveries of previously recorded loan losses of $9.3&nbsp;million, resulting in a net recovery position of $(0.3) million. During 2013, we recognized a
	$6.5&nbsp;million provision for loan losses related to five loans and recorded net recoveries of previously recorded loan losses of $2.2&nbsp;million, resulting in a provision for loan losses, net
	of recoveries of $4.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management
	fees decreased $1.0&nbsp;million, or 9%, for 2014 as compared to 2013, primarily due to recording a portion of the management fee as employee compensation and benefits in
	connection with our CEO's base salary being directly compensated by us effective January&nbsp;1, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Sale of Equity Interest / Incentive Management Fee
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July 2014, we recognized a non-cash gain of approximately $77.1&nbsp;million as a result of our debt guarantee on the 450 West
	33rd&nbsp;Street property being terminated in connection with a refinancing of the existing debt on this property, net of a $19.0&nbsp;million incentive management fee that was prepaid in 2007 in
	relation to the transaction. In December 2014, we sold our remaining interest in the 450 West 33
<SUP>
	rd
</SUP>
	&nbsp;Street property and recognized a gain on sale of $0.8&nbsp;million. We also
	recognized a gain on sale of equity interest of $7.9&nbsp;million in the second quarter of 2014 due to the sale of an interest in properties held by one of our equity affiliates. See
	Note&nbsp;5&#151;"Investments in Equity Affiliates" for further details. There were no such gains in 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	49
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Extinguishment of Debt
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2013, we purchased, at a discount, a $9.9&nbsp;million investment grade rated Class&nbsp;H note originally issued by our CDO
	II and CDO III issuing entity from third party investors and recorded a net gain on early extinguishment of debt of $4.9&nbsp;million. There was no gain on extinguishment of debt in 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Gain on Sale of Real Estate
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2014, we sold three real estate properties in our Multifamily Portfolio for $21.3&nbsp;million and recognized a net gain of
	$1.6&nbsp;million on these sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Preferred Stock Dividends
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Preferred stock dividends increased $2.7&nbsp;million, or 61%, for 2014 as compared to 2013. Dividends on our 8.50% Series&nbsp;C
	preferred stock that were issued in February 2014 contributed $1.6&nbsp;million of this increase, while the full year impact of dividends on our 7.75% Series&nbsp;B preferred stock and our 8.25%
	Series&nbsp;A preferred stock that were issued during 2013 contributed an additional $1.1&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Sources of Liquidity
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Liquidity is a measurement of the ability to meet potential cash requirements. Our short-term and long-term liquidity needs include
	ongoing commitments to repay borrowings, fund future loans and investments, fund operating costs and distributions to our stockholders as well as other general business needs. Our primary sources of
	funds for liquidity consist of proceeds from equity and debt offerings, debt facilities and cash flows from our operations. Our equity sources, depending on market conditions, consist of proceeds from
	capital market transactions including the issuance of common, convertible and/or preferred equity securities. Our debt facilities include the issuance of floating rate notes resulting from our CLOs,
	the issuance of senior unsecured notes and junior subordinated notes and borrowings under warehousing facilities. Net cash flows from operations include interest income from our loan and investment
	portfolio reduced by interest expense
	on our debt facilities, cash generated from our real estate operations, cash from other investments reduced by expenses, repayments of outstanding loans and investments and funds from junior loan
	participation arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	believe our existing sources of funds will be adequate for meeting our short-term and long-term liquidity needs. A majority of our loans and investments are financed under existing
	debt obligations and their credit status is continuously monitored; therefore, these loans and investments are expected to generate a generally stable return. Our ability to meet our long-term
	liquidity and capital resource requirements is subject to obtaining additional debt and equity financing. Any decision by our lenders and investors to enter into such transactions with us will depend
	upon a number of factors, such as our financial performance, compliance with the terms of our existing credit arrangements, industry or market trends, the general availability of and rates applicable
	to financing transactions, such lenders' and investors' resources and policies concerning the terms under which they make such capital commitments and the relative attractiveness of alternative
	investment or lending opportunities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While
	we have been successful in obtaining proceeds from debt and equity offerings, CLOs and certain financing facilities, current conditions in the capital and credit markets have and
	may continue to make certain forms of financing less attractive and, in certain cases, less available. Therefore we will continue to rely, in part, on cash flows provided by operating and investing
	activities for working capital.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To
	maintain our status as a REIT under the Internal Revenue Code, we must distribute annually at least 90% of our REIT-taxable income. These distribution requirements limit our ability
	to retain
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	50
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=53,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=788671,FOLIO='50',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DS76901A.;7',USER='DSLOAN',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:40' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS76901_1_51">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	earnings
	and thereby replenish or increase capital for operations. However, we believe that our capital resources and access to financing will provide us with financial flexibility and market
	responsiveness at levels sufficient to meet current and anticipated capital requirements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Cash Flows
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We generated cash flows from operating activities of $36.3&nbsp;million for 2015, an increase of $5.6&nbsp;million from 2014,
	primarily due to $5.5&nbsp;million of distributions from an equity investment during 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	flows provided by investing activities totaled $24.7&nbsp;million during 2015. Loan and investment activity (originations and payoffs/paydowns) comprise the bulk of our investing
	activities. Loan originations totaling $985.0&nbsp;million were relatively flat compared to loan payoffs and paydowns of $985.8&nbsp;million, resulting in net cash outflow of $0.8&nbsp;million
	related to our loan and investment portfolio. Other significant investing activity included the sale of four real estate owned properties that generated net proceeds of $40.1&nbsp;million and
	investing $19.3&nbsp;million into a residential mortgage banking business. We account for this investment under the equity method of accounting.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	flows provided by financing activities totaled $77.2&nbsp;million during 2015. Significant cash inflows included proceeds of $593.9&nbsp;million from the utilization of our debt
	facilities to fund new loan originations and our CDO/CLO activity, including adding four new term facilities with total availability of $278.5&nbsp;million and increasing the capacity of two
	facilities by $40.0&nbsp;million. We received proceeds of $219.0&nbsp;million from the issuance of CLO IV and $267.8&nbsp;million from the issuance of CLO V and benefited from a
	$169.7&nbsp;million decline in restricted cash balances, primarily from CDO/CLO unwinds. We also received proceeds of $27.2&nbsp;million from the refinancing of a mortgage on our real estate owned
	assets. Significant cash outflows included $636.9&nbsp;million in payoffs and paydowns of our debt facilities, including the payoff of an $87.0&nbsp;million facility entered into in March 2015 in
	connection with the acquisition of a $116.0&nbsp;million first mortgage and the payoff of a $15.0&nbsp;million line of credit. The redemption of all three of our CDO vehicles resulted in outflows
	totaling $312.1&nbsp;million while the redemption of CLO II resulted in outflows of $177.0&nbsp;million. We also made payments totaling $31.0&nbsp;million on a mortgage note related to our real
	estate owned assets and paid distributions totaling $37.0&nbsp;million to our common and preferred stockholders.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_16"></A>

	Debt Facilities
</I>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We maintain various forms of short-term and long-term financing arrangements. Borrowings underlying these arrangements are primarily
	secured by a significant amount of our loans and investments. The following is a summary of our debt facilities:
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:67%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">

<FONT SIZE=2>

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Principal
	balance excludes the impact of deferred financing costs.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">

	Maturity
	dates represent the weighted average remaining maturity based on the underlying collateral as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.

<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	51
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=54,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=841270,FOLIO='51',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DS76901A.;7',USER='DSLOAN',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:40' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS76901_1_52">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(3)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	a total face amount of $175.9&nbsp;million less a total deferred amount of $15.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;These
	debt facilities, including their restrictive covenants, are described in further detail in Note&nbsp;7&#151;"Debt Obligations."
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	CLO vehicles contain interest coverage and asset over collateralization covenants that must be met as of the waterfall distribution date in order for us to receive such payments. If
	we fail these covenants any of our CLOs, all cash flows from the applicable CLO would be diverted to repay principal and interest on the outstanding CLO bonds and we would not receive any residual
	payments until that CLO regained compliance with such tests. Our CLOs were in compliance with all such covenants as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 as well as on the most recent determination dates in
	January and February 2016. In the event of a breach of the CLO covenants that could not be cured in the near-term, we would be required to fund our non-CLO expenses, including management fees and
	employee costs, distributions required to maintain our REIT status, debt costs, and other expenses with (i)&nbsp;cash on hand, (ii)&nbsp;income from any CLO not in breach of a covenant test,
	(iii)&nbsp;income from real property and loan assets, (iv)&nbsp;sale of assets, or (v)&nbsp;or accessing the equity or debt capital markets, if available. We have the right to cure covenant
	breaches, which would resume normal residual payments to us by purchasing non-performing loans out of the CLOs. However, we may not have sufficient liquidity available to do so at such time.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_17"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Contractual Commitments
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had the following material contractual obligations (in thousands):
</FONT>
</P>

<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	principal amounts due based on contractual maturities. Does not include total projected interest payments on our debt obligations of
	$37.7&nbsp;million in 2016, $32.6&nbsp;million in 2017, $25.0&nbsp;million in 2018, $18.2&nbsp;million in 2019, $13.6&nbsp;million in 2020 and $84.9&nbsp;million thereafter based on
	current LIBOR rates.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Comprised
	of $281.2&nbsp;million of CLO III debt, $219.0&nbsp;million of CLO IV debt and $267.8&nbsp;million of CLO V debt with a weighted average
	contractual maturity of 1.67, 2.51 and 2.93&nbsp;years, respectively, as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(3)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	the face amount due upon maturity. The carrying value is $157.1&nbsp;million, which is net of a deferred amount of $15.5&nbsp;million and
	deferred financing fees of $3.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(4)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	accordance with certain loans and investments, we have outstanding unfunded commitments of $11.5&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, that we
	are obligated to fund as the borrowers meet certain requirements. Specific requirements include, but are not limited to, property renovations,
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	52
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=55,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=878060,FOLIO='52',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DS76901A.;7',USER='DSLOAN',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:40' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS76901_1_53">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	building
	construction and building conversions based on criteria met by the borrower in accordance with the loan agreements. The payment due by period is based on the maturity date of underlying loans
	and is included in loans and investments, net on the consolidated balance sheet. Our restricted cash balance contained $3.1&nbsp;million which was available to fund the portion of the unfunded
	commitments for loans financed by our CLO vehicles.
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Off-Balance-Sheet Arrangements
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2015, we did not have any off-balance-sheet arrangements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Inflation
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Changes in the general level of interest rates prevailing in the economy in response to changes in the rate of inflation generally have
	little effect on our income because the majority of our interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have floating rates of interest. However, the significant decline in interest rates in
	the past triggered LIBOR floors on certain of our variable rate interest-earning assets. This resulted in an increase in interest rate spreads on certain assets as the rates we pay on variable rate
	interest-bearing liabilities declined at a greater pace than the rates we earned on our variable rate interest-earning assets. Additionally, we have various fixed rate loans in our portfolio which are
	financed with variable rate LIBOR borrowings. In connection with these loans, we have entered into various interest swaps to hedge our exposure to the interest rate risk on our variable rate LIBOR
	borrowings as it relates to certain fixed rate loans in our portfolio. However, the value of our interest-earning assets, our ability to realize gains from the sale of assets, and the average life of
	our interest-earning assets, among other things, may be affected. See "Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk" below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Agreements and Transactions with Related Parties
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have a management agreement with our Manager, pursuant to which our Manager provides certain services and we pay our Manager a base
	management fee and under certain circumstances, an annual incentive fee. We incurred $10.9&nbsp;million, $9.9&nbsp;million and $10.9&nbsp;million of base management fees for services rendered in
	2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	base management fee is an arrangement whereby we reimburse our Manager for its actual costs incurred in managing our business based on the parties' agreement in advance on an annual
	budget with subsequent quarterly true-ups to actual costs. All origination fees on investments are retained by us.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	addition, we have conducted many transactions with our Manager and other parties that are deemed related party transactions. The details of the management agreement and related party
	transactions are described in Note&nbsp;14&#151;"Agreements and Transactions with Related Parties" of this report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	June 2013, our Board of Directors formed a special committee consisting of independent directors in connection with the exploration and evaluation of a potential transaction with our
	Manager involving the acquisition of our Manager's Fannie Mae, DUS, Freddie Mac, FHA and CMBS platforms, as well as the internalization of the management of our current business. In late June of 2014,
	preliminary discussions regarding a possible transaction resumed and in February 2016, we entered into a definitive
	agreement to acquire the agency platform of our Manager for $250.0&nbsp;million. See Note&nbsp;18&#151;"Subsequent Event" for further details. In connection with evaluating this potential
	transaction, we incurred advisory fees totaling $3.1&nbsp;million and $1.4&nbsp;million during 2015 and 2013, respectively. No such expenses were incurred during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	53
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=56,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=487426,FOLIO='53',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DS76901A.;7',USER='DSLOAN',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:40' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS76901_1_54">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Significant Accounting Estimates and Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management's discussion and analysis of financial condition and results of operations is based upon our consolidated financial
	statements, which have been prepared in accordance with the Financial Accounting Standards Board Accounting Standards Codification&#153;, the authoritative reference for accounting principles
	generally accepted in the U.S. ("GAAP"). The preparation of financial statements in conformity with GAAP requires the use of estimates and assumptions that could affect the reported amounts in our
	consolidated financial statements. Actual results could differ from these estimates. A summary of our significant accounting policies is presented in Note&nbsp;2&#151;"Summary of Significant
	Accounting Policies." Set forth below are the accounting policies that management believes are critical to the preparation of the consolidated financial statements included in this
	report:
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Loans, Investments and Securities
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Impaired Loans, Allowance for Loan Losses and
	Charge-offs
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Real Estate Owned and Held-For-Sale
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Revenue Recognition
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Hedging Activities and Derivatives
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#149;
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Variable Interest Entities
</I>
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
	of the accounting policies used in the preparation of these consolidated financial statements are particularly important for an understanding of the financial position and
	results of operations presented in the historical consolidated financial statements included in this report and require the application of significant judgment by management and, as a result, are
	subject to a degree of uncertainty.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Non-GAAP Financial Measures
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Funds from Operations and Adjusted Funds from Operations
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We present funds from operations ("FFO") and adjusted funds from operations ("AFFO") because we believe they are important supplemental
	measures of our operating performance in that they are frequently used by analysts, investors and other parties in the evaluation of REITs. The National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts,
	or NAREIT, defines FFO as net income (loss) attributable to common stockholders (computed in accordance with GAAP), excluding gains (losses) from sales of depreciated real properties, plus impairments
	of depreciated properties and real estate related depreciation and amortization, and after adjustments for unconsolidated ventures.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	define AFFO as funds from operations adjusted for accounting items such as non-cash stock-based compensation expense, as well as the add-back of impairment losses on real estate and
	gains/losses on sales of real estate. We are generally not in the business of operating real estate owned property and have obtained real estate by foreclosure or through partial or full settlement of
	mortgage debt related to our loans to maximize the value of the collateral and minimize our exposure. Therefore, we deem such impairment and gains/losses on real estate as an extension of the asset
	management of our loans, thus a recovery of principal or additional loss on our initial investment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;FFO
	and AFFO are not intended to be an indication of our cash flow from operating activities (determined in accordance with GAAP) or a measure of our liquidity, nor is it entirely
	indicative of funding our cash needs, including our ability to make cash distributions. Our calculation of FFO and AFFO may be different from the calculations used by other companies and, therefore,
	comparability may be limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	54
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-LEFT:10PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Net income attributable to common stockholders
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>

</FONT>
</TD>
<TD ALIGN="RIGHT" VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	45,875,094
</FONT>
</TD>
<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">

<TD VALIGN="BOTTOM" STYLE="LINE-HEIGHT:0PT;FONT-SIZE:1.5PT;FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;BORDER-BOTTOM:SOLID #000000 1.0PT;">

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Excluding
	the impact of a $58.1&nbsp;million non-cash net gain related to the 450 West 33rd&nbsp;Street transaction (see Note&nbsp;14&#151;"Agreements and Transactions with
	Related Parties" for further details), FFO for 2014 was $34.0&nbsp;million, or $0.68 per diluted common share and AFFO for 2014 was $37.3&nbsp;million, or $0.74 per diluted common share.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_MARKET_RISK>
<A NAME="FIS_MARKET_RISK"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_DS76901_ITEM_7A__QUANTITATIVE_AND_QUAL__ITE02669">
</A>
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_TOC_DS76901_1">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	Item&nbsp;7A.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Market risk is the exposure to loss resulting from changes in interest rates, foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices, equity
	prices and real estate values. The primary market risks that we are exposed to are real estate risk and interest rate risk.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Market Conditions
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are subject to market changes in the debt and secondary mortgage markets. These markets have experienced disruptions in the past,
	which have and may in the future have an adverse impact on our earnings and financial condition.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	general, credit markets have experienced difficulty over the past several years. However, of late, we have been able to access equity and debt markets through equity and debt
	offerings and the issuance of CLOs. While there can be no assurance that we will continue to have access to the equity and debt markets, we will continue to pursue these and other available market
	opportunities as means to increase our liquidity and capital base.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Real Estate Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commercial mortgage assets may be viewed as exposing an investor to greater risk of loss than residential mortgage assets since such
	assets are typically secured by larger loans to fewer obligors than residential mortgage assets. Multifamily and commercial property values and net operating income
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	55
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=58,EFW="2227477",CP="ARBOR REALTY TRUST, INC.",DN="1",CHK=850063,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK129:[15ZCW1.15ZCW76901]DS76901A.;7',USER='DSLOAN',CD='25-FEB-2016;11:40' -->
<A NAME="A2227477Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DS76901_1_56">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227477Z10-K_HTM_BG76901A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	derived
	from such properties are subject to volatility and may be affected adversely by a number of factors, including, but not limited to, events such as natural disasters including hurricanes and
	earthquakes, acts of war and/or terrorism and others that may cause unanticipated and uninsured performance declines and/or losses to us or the owners and operators of the real estate securing our
	investment; national, regional and local economic conditions (which may be adversely affected by industry slowdowns and other factors); local real estate conditions (such as an oversupply of housing,
	retail, industrial, office or other commercial space); changes or continued weakness in specific industry segments; construction quality, construction delays, construction cost, age and design;
	demographic factors; retroactive changes to building or similar codes; and increases in operating expenses (such as energy costs). In the event net operating income decreases, a borrower may have
	difficulty repaying our loans, which could result in losses to us. In addition, decreases in property values reducing the value of collateral, and a lack of liquidity in the market, could reduce the
	potential proceeds available to a borrower to repay our loans, which could also cause us to suffer losses. Even when the net operating income is sufficient to cover the related property's debt
	service, there can be no assurance that this will continue to be the case in the future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Interest Rate Risk
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest rate risk is highly sensitive to many factors, including governmental monetary and tax policies, domestic and international
	economic and political considerations and other factors beyond our control.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	operating results depend in large part on differences between the income from our loans and our borrowing costs. Most of our loans and borrowings are variable-rate instruments, based
	on LIBOR. The objective of this strategy is to minimize the impact of interest rate changes on our net interest income. In addition, we have various fixed rate loans in our portfolio, which are
	financed with variable rate LIBOR borrowings. We have entered into various interest swaps (as discussed below) to hedge our exposure to interest rate risk on our variable rate LIBOR borrowings as it
	relates to our fixed rate loans. Certain of these swaps are scheduled to mature on the original maturity dates of their corresponding loans. However, loans are sometimes extended and, consequently, do
	not pay off on their original maturity dates. If a loan is extended, whether it is through an existing extension option or a modification, our exposure to interest rate risk may be increased. In these
	instances, we could have a fixed rate loan in our portfolio financed with variable debt and, since the corresponding interest swap already matured, a portion of our debt is no longer protected against
	interest rate risk. Some of our loans and borrowings are subject to various interest rate floors. As a result, the impact of a change in interest rates may be different on our interest income than it
	is on our interest expense.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	have utilized interest rate swaps to limit interest rate risk. Derivatives are used for hedging purposes rather than speculation. We do not enter into financial instruments for
	trading purposes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	following table projects the potential impact on interest income and interest expense for a 12-month period, and the potential change in fair value of our derivative financial
	instruments as of
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	56
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	December&nbsp;31,
	2015, assuming an instantaneous increase or decrease of both 25 and 50 basis points in LIBOR and forward interest rate curves, adjusted for the effects of our interest rate hedging
	activities.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(1)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Represents
	the unpaid principal balance of our loan portfolio and the net fair value of our derivative financial instruments, which includes interest rate
	swaps, basis swaps and LIBOR caps.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(2)
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Assumes
	the LIBOR rate will not decrease below zero. The quoted one-month LIBOR rate was 0.43% as December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	the event of a significant rising interest rate environment and/or economic downturn, defaults could increase and result in credit losses to us, which could adversely affect our
	liquidity and operating results. Further, such delinquencies or defaults could have an adverse effect on the spreads between interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	57
</FONT>
</P>
